PURPOSE

This document provides for control of the executive summary information to be included in the Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) submittal to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The executive summary identifies hazards associated with operation of Loveland Products, Inc.-Billings (LPI-Billings) and describes practices in place to mitigate those hazards.  This information is available to local emergency response groups.  It is also available to the public in limited form.  This document also provides for control of other information required to be submitted in the Risk Management Plan.



This document should be reviewed for required changes whenever the RMPlan is updated.



REFERENCES



Department of Labor (OSHA), 29 CFR part 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, February 24, 1992



Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule, 40 CFR part 68, Final Rule, June 20, 1996



PROCEDURE



How Coverage was Determined for Loveland Products Inc.- Billings



Dimethylamine is listed in the RMP rule and is stored above the threshold quantity at Loveland Products, Inc.-Billings.  EPA's RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case and alternative release scenarios.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Stationary Source Description and Use of RMP Regulated Substances



Loveland Products, Inc.-Billings (LPI-Billings) is located in Section 26, Township 1 North, Range 26 East in Yellowstone County, Montana and encompasses approximately 27 acres.  LPI-Billings is a subdivision of Crop Protection Services (CPS).  LPI-Billings operates a herbicide formulation facility which blends and reacts raw technical active herbicide ingredients with alcohols, solvents, amines or water to produce finished products.



Dimethylamine (DMA) is used to produce herbicides through the amination of technically active herbicide ingredients.  The DMA amination process consists of a 60% aqueous solution of DMA along with a bulk active solid in a bat

ch process creating a liquid finished herbicide. 



WORST -CASE SCENARIO (WCS)



The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a flammable substance at LPI-Billings is the loss of containment of a 25,000 gallon railcar of 60% dimethylamine (DMA)or 99,000 lbs. at 1 psi pressure. Although controls are in place to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario. The maximum distance to the worst-case flammable endpoint is 0.30 miles.



The real life preventative measures which are not considered in the WCS evaluation are:

       * DOT pressurized tank car specified for DMA transportation and handling 

       * Nitrogen purge preventing DMA vapor release to atmosphere and eliminating static air in the tank car

       * Maintenance and inspection programs to monitor equipment integrity 

       * In-house operating and startup procedures

       * Operators montor flow through automation system for quick response to process deviations

       * Inventory minimization during non-DMA production periods

       * Process has failclose valves before and after DMA pump and one at the blend vessel

       * Manual shut-off of DMA system

With these practices in place, LPI-Billings considers the complete release of a full 25,000 gallon tank car to be a low probability.



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO (ARS)



The alternate case scenario has been determined to be a compromise in a transfer line outside of the building between the railcar and the reacting vessel.  The largest potential loss of DMA would occur during a transfer which would be discovered and addressed within 10 minutes of the transfer startup.  Based off of the actual gpm transfer of 60% DMA over a 10 minute timeframe, the calculated amount of DMA that would potentially be released is 1295 lbs. or 188 gallons. The maximum distance to the flamable endpoint is 0.08 miles.  Accident pr

evention measures in-place to minimize a DMA release include:

       * Process has failclose valves before and after DMA pump and one at the blend vessel

       * Operators montor flow through automation system for quick response to process deviations

       * Maintenance and inspection programs to monitor equipment integrity 

       * In-house operating and startup procedures include operator walking the lines at startup

       * Operators are trained on emergency operations and process deviations

Although these measures are in place and the likelihood of this ARS happening is low, LPI-Billings personnel selected this scenario to be the most probable to occur.  



GENERAL ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at LPI-Billings.  Processes regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard.  This summary addresses the OSHA PSM elements applicable to RMP and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.  The administrative procedures used for process safety management have been revised to incorporate all RMP required items and these procedures are now considered PSM/RMP administrative procedures.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



LPI-Billings encourages employees to participate in plant safety.  PSM/RMP elements include employee participation through writing and updating operating and maintenance procedures, compiling process safety information and participating in process hazard analysis'.  Additionally, employee's have been instructed to come forward with their safety concerns.  Process' that fall under RMP requirements already are subject to PSM requirements.  Programs are in place that address both PSM and RMP regulations.  All PSM/RMP materials are available to employees.



Additional detail, including responsibilities, may be found in PSM-ADM-02 of the PSM administrative procedure.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATON (PSI)

LPI-Billings PSI package is a compilation of information about the technology, hazards and equipment of PSM/RMP covered processes.  LPI-Billings PSI consists of the 12 following sections:

      1.  The PSI administrative procedure

      2.  Process Description - a description of the process purpose and major processing steps.  

             The function of all major equipment is described, along with the interactions between the equipment.     

      3.  Process Chemistry - qualitative chemical reaction descriptions are provided.

      4.  Process Flow Diagrams - provides pertinent information necessary to understand process basics. 

              Diagrams in thissection indicate major process equipment, flow directions, pressures, temperatures,

              and instrument components.  

      5.  Maximum Intended Inventory - identifies major pieces of equipment in the process, and qualifies the 

              maximum normal inventories of PSM/RMP covered chemicals that can be expected within this 

              equipment.

      6.  Safe Operating Limits - identifies safe upper and lower operating limits for process control variables     

              within the PSM/RMP covered process.  Control variables include pressure, flow, level, composition

              and temperature.  This section also includes clear consequences of deviation from the safe upper 

              and lower limits as well as the actions to prevent or correct conditions outside of the

              operating limits.

      7.  Chemical Hazard Information - lists the chemicals within the PSM/RMP covered process, 

              along with information pertaining to the hazards of these chemicals.

      8.  Inadvertent Mixing Information - outlines the consequences of inadvertently mixing chemicals utilized in 

              the PSM/RMP covered processes.  This section includes reactant names,  

              conditions of reaction, results of reaction, likelihood of occurri

ng, steps for handling the reaction,   

              and safeguards to prevent the reaction.

      9.  Piping and Instrument Diagrams (P&ID;s) - includes all equipment components, piping s and 

              flow directions, valve  and type, presence of insulation and heat tracing, auxilary connections,  

              utility connections, and instrument identification symbols.

     10.  Process Equipment Data - includes equipment subsections with the following:     

              equipment summaries, piping design schedules, relief system design, mechanical and  

              instrument safety systems, electrical area classification, ventilation system design and fire

              safety systems.

      11. Supporting Documentation - includes subsections with the following: engineering standard  

              documentation, equipment drawings and relief system calculations.

      12. References



Additionally, complete files on PSM/RMP covered equipment are located in mechanical integrity documentation.  The PSI package is PSM-ADM-03 in the PSM administrative procedure.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



LPI- Billings has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various units within our process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each unit is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



The techniques LPI-Billings uses in it PHA's are the What If/Checklist and HAZOP analysis for specific nodes.  The HAZOP technique is one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluations available.  All PHA's are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process and makes recommendations for additional prevention and safety measures or design changes when the team believes such actions are necessary.



Local management reviews

the PHA Team recommendations, and employees are assigned accountability to resolve all recommendations that have been made by the PHA team and accepted by local management.  Implementation of recommendations in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA Team.  The ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios are assigned the highest risk ranking and thus receive immediate attention.  All approved recommendations being implemented in response to PHA Team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.  Upon completion of all recommendations for a specific PHA, a final report is issued that all affected employees can access, thus having knowledge that all the recommendations for the PHA have been resolved.  To insure process safety at LPI-Billings, each process is required to have a PHA revalidation every five years. 



Additional detail, including responsibilities, can be found in the Process Hazard Analysis procedure (PSM-ADM-04).



OPERATING PROCEDURES



LPI-Billings maintains written operating procedures for normal operations and emergency procedures.  Startup and shutdown procedures are included in the normal operating procedures since LPI-Billings produces in batches.  Emergency procedures include the assignment of responsibility of shutdown and startup procedures.  Included in the operating procedures is guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process steps or equipment parameter deviations.



These procedures are used by operators and are used in the training of new operators.  All procedures are reviewed at least annually by the area supervisor.  Whenever a change is required the management of change procedure is initiated.  Operating procedures are readily available to the operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their tasks.



Additional information, inclu

ding responsibilities can be found PSM-ADM-05 of the PSM administrative procedure.



TRAINING



To complement the written procedures for process operations, LPI-Billings has implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  When new operators can demonstrate through tests or skills demonstration that they have the knowledge necessry to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner, they may be qualified for a job position and allowed to work independently.  In addition, all operators are updated when ever a process change occurs and are periodically given refresher training on the operating procedures.



Additional information, including responsibilities can be found in PSM-ADM-06 of the PSM administrative procedure and LPI-Billings Written Safety Plan.



CONTRACTORS



LPI-Billings uses contractors to supplement its workforce for peak production periods and for specialty work.  Procedures are in place to ensure contractors perform their work in a safe manner, have the appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards in their work place, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand site safety rules and comply with all site specific safety requirements.  



Contractors are orientated on site safety and health hazards, task safety and health hazards, emergency response and evacuation information, and safe work practices for the site and their duties.



Part of LPI-Billings' contractor program is a safety performance review of a contractor prior to hiring the contractor. Once 

oriented the cotractor's performance is  monitored while working at LPI-Billings to ensure the contractor is using safe work practices.  If a contractor is not fulfilling his/her safety obligations, LPI-Billings will reque

st the contractor come into 

compliance or dismiss the contractor.



Additional information, including responsibilities, may be found in PSM-ADM-07 of the PSM administrative procedure.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)



LPI-Billings conducts a PSSR for any new process or a process modification.  The purpose of the PSSR is a final check to ensure safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment have been preparred for the change.  The PSSR check list 

verifies all aspects of readiness and serves a quality assurance function.



Additional information, including responsibilities, may be found in PSM-ADM-08 of the PSM administrative procedure.  



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY (MI)



Mechanical integrity systems are maintained and documented at LPI-Billings for the following PSM covered equipment: 

        pressure vessels, exchangers, columns and tanks

        piping and piping components

        relief devices

        pumps

        instrumentation/controls

        emergency systems

The MI program outlines training, mechanical procedures, inspections and tests, identifying and correction of 

deficiencies and quality assurance measures.  Aspects of the mechanical integrity program were designated to 

comply with all government and manufacturer requirements.



Maintenance training includes process overviews, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans and safe work practices.



In the case of an equipment deficiency, employees will correct the deficiency prior to placing the equipment back into service or a team will review the equipment use and determine what actions are necessary to ensure safe operation of the equipment.  Equipment that cannot be safely operated will be kept out of service until the deficiency is corrected.



Quality assurance measures are incorporated in equipment purchase and repairs to make certain new equipment is suitable for its intended use and proper materials/parts are used when r

epairs are made.



Additional MI information, including responsibilities, may be found in PSM-ADM-09 of the PSM administrative procedure and our mechanical integrity manual.



SAFE WORK PRACTICES (SWP)



LPI-Billings safe work practices include but are not limited to:

     Hot work authorization, permitting and training

     Lockout/Tagout authorization, permitting and training

     Line breaking authorization, permitting and training

     Incident reporting and reviews with employees

     Air monitoring and reviews with employees

     Contractor orientation

     Confined Space authorization, permitting and training

     Personal Protective Equipment reviews and training

     HazCom programs and training

     Housekeeping training

     Emergency evacuation training



These procedures and other safety procedures may be found in LPI-Billings Written Safety Plan.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (MOC)



LPI-Billings MOC program requires changes to process equipment, chemicals, technology, operating procedures and other process changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, verify existing controls have not been compromised, and identify changes that need to be made for safe process operations.  Once any identified changes are made, LPI-Billings' PSM is updated and employees involved in or near the process are provided training on the change.



Additional information, including responsibilities may be found in PSM-ADM-11 of LPI-Billings PSM administrative procedure.  



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



LPI-Billings investigates all incidents that activates LPI-Billings emergency response system or could potentially result in a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss or personal injury.  The incident investigation is conducted by a team that reviews the event, documents its findings, and develops corrective actions to prevent a repeat incid

ent.  Once the investigation is complete, employees and contractors are made aware of the incident findings and the actions that will be taken to prevent future like incidents.  Incident investigation reports are retained at least 5 years and are included in LPI-Billings PHAs.



Additional information about LPI-Billings incident investigation process may be found in PSM-ADM-12 of LPI-Billings PSM adminitrative procedure.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS



LPI-Billings PSM audit includes field verification of actions, policies, and required documents to ensure actual practice and compliance with the PSM Compliance Plan.  The PSM Audit Team will verify whether materials needed to support each audit element are in place and up-to-date.  Upon completion of the audit, the PSM Audit Team and management reviews the findings. Any items requiring follow-up will be assigned to appropriate personnel and a completion date will be assigned.  The audit and followup actions will be maintained in LPI-Billings PSM compliance files.



Additional information, including responsibility, may be found in PSM-ADM-14 of LPI-Billings administrative procedure.



TRADE SECRETS



Although confidentiality agreements may be required at LPI-Billings, trade secrets will never be allowed to interfere with the dissemination of information required for ensuring the safety of employees, contractors, customers and members of the public.  All process information needed by employees or contractors to safely perform their job assignments shall be made available without regard to possible trade secret status.



Additional information on trade secrets, including responsibility, may be found in PSM-ADM-15 of LPI-Billings administrative procedure.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Over the past 5 years LPI-Billings experienced one incident in the PSM/RMP process that DID NOT result in an employee injury, equipment damage, require evacuation or impact the community. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



LPI-Bi

llings maintains a contingency plan in compliance with 40 CFR Parts 264 and 265, Subpart D.  Related emergency planning requirements covered are 

      29 CFR Part 1910.38(a), Employee Emergency Plans,

      29 CFR Part 1010.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals,

      29 CFR Part 1910.120, Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response,

      40 CFR Part 68, Risk Management Program Rule,

      40 CFR Part 112, Oil Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures

LPI-Billings Contingency Plan along with LPI-Billings Preparedness Plan are designated to minimize emergencies which could threaten human health or the environment.  The provisions of the Contingency Pan are immediately implemented whenever there is a fire, explosion, or release of hazardous material or hazardous waste which could harm personnel on the LPI-Billings site, endanger the neighboring community or cause damage to the environment.  Arrangements have been made with Lockwood Rural Fire District #8 to take the lead if an emergency occurred.  Other organizations that have agreed to respond in the event of an emergency are Yellowstone County Sheriff Department, Saint Vincent's Hospital and Health Center, Billings Clinic of Billings, Montana Department Of Environmental Quality, Montana State Disaster and Emergency Services Division, U.S. EPA (Region VIII, Montana Office), City of Billings Fire Department, U.R.S.Corp. and several local vendors. 



The contingency and preparedness and prevention plans are accessible to all employees.  Every employee and contractor is familiarized with the plant alarm system, evacuation procedures and how to perform any assigned responsibility or duty.  Periodic evacuation drills are conducted to refresh workers on alarms and evacuation procedures.  When ever a change is made to either emergency response document, LPI-Billings employees and contractors are notified and trained (if necessary) on the change.



In the event an incident threatens

to go beyond LPI-Billings boundaries, neighboring facilities would be contacted and if needed the community warning siren system would be activated.  The Yellowstone County Local Emergency Planning Committee (YC-LEPC) has coordinated programs along with industry to address public notification, emergency response procedures and emergency medical procedures in the event an incident threatens the community.
